title: In CA what are the affirmative defenses in a credit card default case where the causes of action are common counts?
question: The counts are: Within 4 years defendant became indebted to the plaintiff:
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal charges,Fraud,Duress and criminal charges
answers:
I agree with my colleagues. If you are asking for advice in drafting your answer, I highly recommend you consult with an attorney to help you through the process. If you are interested in bankruptcy, you should file instead of answering the civil complaint - just to save the cost of the filing fee. If you have questions, my office is located in San Francisco and we take (and win) these types of cases all the time.

Good luck,

Otis C. Landerholm, Esq.
www.LanderholmBankruptcy.com

- duress
- estoppel
- set off
- failure of consideration
- fraud (generally, as an equitable defense, as opposed to fraud in the inducement, below)
- fraud in the inducement
- illegality
- laches
- release
- statute of frauds
- statute of limitations
- waiver
- unclean hands
- failure to mitigate damages (or, in some circumstances, successful mitigation of damages)
- rejection of goods
- revocation of acceptance of goods
- conditions precedent
- no reliance
- lack of standing ...

... to name a few

I'm not entirely clear on your question. You have listed 4 options under the Common Counts form pleading from which the plaintiff may check the pertinent boxes. Your defenses depend on what facts you have to show you don't owe the money. Many times, a defendant (you) can file a "General Denial" and attach the so-called, Generic Defenses, (statute of limitations, lack of standing, debt owed by another, etc) unless the complaint is "verified" by the plaintiff. You need to see an attorney on this. Of course, if you are eligible to file BK, the lawsuit goes away and will be discharged by the BK court. You can contact me by phone or email if you still have specific questions.
